Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: the nave of the Arcibasilica di Nostra Signora

A historic home to the most faithful, this pristine white marble building has stood the test of time as it remains tall and proud throughout the years. The exquisite carving of the architecture represents a symbol of the care and patience that was given to make this immaculate building come to life. Lofty, marble pillars adorn the central aisle of the walkway that consists of intricate statues built within depicting important figures. The soaring, domed ceiling is crafted completely of delicate stained glass. It is embellished with murals of the faith, causing various hues of color to shimmer throughout the room when the sun touches. Rows of pristine marble pews flank each side of the aisle to give an area of comfort beneath the lord and savior to loyal members. Standing on the left side in the northern area of the room is a highly polished pulpit stand in the shape of a perfect cross. An exit in the eastern area of the room leads to a small confessional and a modest chapel to the west.

a pair of ornate mahogany doors leading east
A pair of mahogany doors featuring ornate carvings leads east into either side of a confessional booth. $(parent-desc)
an ornate pair of doors leading northeast
The nave of the Arcibasilica di Nostra Signora leads to the northeast. $(parent-desc)

These massive doors leading southwest look heavy and solid. They are made of solid oak banded with polished brass. In the center of each door is a blazing cross symbol done in gold leaf. Goldwork filigree traces each door delicately, reflecting the light and granting an unearthly glow to the wood. $(parent-desc)
an ornate pair of doors leading northwest
The nave of the Arcibasilica di Nostra Signora leads to the northwest. $(parent-desc)

These massive doors leading southwest look heavy and solid. They are made of solid oak banded with polished brass. In the center of each door is a blazing cross symbol done in gold leaf. Goldwork filigree traces each door delicately, reflecting the light and granting an unearthly glow to the wood. $(parent-desc)
a white marble arch leading south

The arch stands directly in the middle of the low wall separating the narthex from the nave. It is symbolic, for the wall is low enough for a person to climb without difficulty. The arch is made of smooth white marble, streaked with ribbons of silver. It is wide enough for two people to comfortably walk abreast and twice as tall as a man The sides of the arch are carved with climbing vines, and at the apex is a carving of the sun with rays radiating from all sides. $(parent-desc)
The white marble arch stands directly in the middle of the low wall separating the narthex from the nave. $(parent-desc)
an ornate door leading west
This door is rather ornate, constructed of a pale wood polished to a nearly pristine white. Gold paneling is covered in holy symbols, with an image of Mary predominating. $(parent-desc)
This door is rather ornate, constructed of a pale wood polished to a nearly pristine white. $(parent-desc)
the eastern aisle

This is a passageway to the east of the nave, leading to the eastern transept. It allows one passage around the nave to the north end of the church. The aisle is separated from the nave on the west side by a colonnade, a series of gleaming marble columns. The roof of the aisle is lower than the rest of the cathedral and supported by vast arches stretching from each column to the eastern wall. Clerestory windows allow light in during the day and glow brightly at dawn, illuminating stained-glass in the shapes of eight-pointed stars.

This is a passageway to the east of the nave, leading to the eastern transept. It allows one passage around the nave to the north end of the church. The aisle is separated from the nave on the west side by a colonnade, a series of gleaming marble columns.
the western aisle

This is a passageway to the west of the nave, leading to the western transept. It allows one passage around the nave to the north end of the church. The aisle is separated from the nave on the east side by a colonnade, a series of gleaming marble columns. The roof of the aisle is lower than the rest of the cathedral and supported by vast arches stretching from each column to the western wall. Clerestory windows allow light in during the day and glow brightly at dusk, illuminating stained-glass in the shapes of eight-pointed stars.

This is a passageway to the west of the nave, leading to the western transept. It allows one passage around the nave to the north end of the church. The aisle is separated from the nave on the east side by a colonnade, a series of gleaming marble columns.
the high altar

The high altar is a free-standing block of white marble, six feet wide by three feet high by three feet deep. The top of the altar is draped with a gold satin cloth. Along the sides of the altar are carved holy images of Saint Mary and cross symbols. It is said that within the altar lies a sepulcher that contains the vestments worn by Saint Mary.

The high altar is a free-standing block of white marble, six feet wide by three feet high by three feet deep. The top of the altar is draped with a gold satin cloth. Along the sides of the altar are carved holy images of Saint Mary and cross symbols.
the ambulatory

This is a passageway that wraps around the perimeter of the north end of the cathedral, starting at each transept and surrounding the choir and sanctuary. It allows one passage directly from either transept to the chapel, and vice-versa. The ambulatory is separated from the rest of the cathedral by an arcade of gleaming marble columns. The roof of the ambulatory is lower than the rest of the cathedral and supported by vast arches stretching from each column to the surrounding walls. Clerestory windows on the east and west walls allow light in during the day and various depictions of Saint Mary in stained glass.

This is a passageway that wraps around the perimeter of the north end of the cathedral, starting at each transept and surrounding the choir and sanctuary. It allows one passage directly from either transept to the chapel, and vice-versa. The ambulatory is separated from the rest of the cathedral by an arcade of gleaming marble columns.
a statue of Andrew, The First Chosen

Carved in polished marble is a historic statue of a tall man draped in an ankle-length tunic. His feet bear no coverage, and the top of his head is covered with a lengthy headscarf that wraps twice around his neck before cascading over his tunic. He has round eyes and a narrow line of facial hair that covers his jawline and chin. A prominent nose and bushy eyebrows complete his face. His hands are clasped together and brought upward to his chest as if in prayer. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Andrew, The First Chosen-.

Carved in polished marble is a historic statue of a tall man draped in an ankle-length tunic. His feet bear no coverage, and the top of his head is covered with a lengthy headscarf that wraps twice around his neck before cascading over his tunic. He has round eyes and a narrow line of facial hair that covers his jawline and chin. A prominent nose and bushy eyebrows complete his face. His hands are clasped together and brought upward to his chest as if in prayer. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Andrew, The First Chosen-.
padded white bench

A small bench sits at the north end of the choir. The frame of the bench appears to be iron, fancily wrought and painted white. The seat and back of the bench are covered in cushions upholstered with gold-colored satin and appear fairly comfortable. The bench is large enough to seat perhaps four priests in comfort.
A small white bench padded with gold cushions sits in the north end of the choir.
the ceiling

The ceiling stretches far, far overhead. It is supported by numerous striped arches that meet each other at right angles and even stack on top of one another. The ceiling itself is given a pristine whitewash and is lit well enough from below that none of it lies in shadow. Between the arches are painted intricate swirling shapes and circles interlocked in a complex design.
The ceiling far overhead arches upward toward the magnificent dome in the center of the cathedral, becoming difficult to discern as it fades into the distant brightness.
the choir

The choir is an area just north of the crossing in the center of the cathedral, south of the sanctuary. Two small stages for singers are located on the east and west side of the choir. The eastern stage holds alto and tenor singers, while the western stage holds bass and soprano singers. A small bench for attendant priests sits in the north end of the choir, against the south side of the platform holding the sanctuary.

The choir is an area just north of the crossing in the center of the cathedral, south of the sanctuary. Two small stages for singers are located on the east and west side of the choir, while a small bench for attendant priests sits in the north end of the choir, against the south side of the platform holding the sanctuary.
the stained glass dome

Far, far above is a stained-glass dome exposing the sky to all within the cathedral. As you stare upward, the infinite celestial grandeur of the distant sky pulls you toward it, lifting your spirit and swallowing you in the vast wonder of nature. Sunlight fills the cathedral with brilliance, gracing every detail with a nimbus of spectral holy light.The glittering night hangs above, moonlight bathing the cathedral in a soft, soothing peaceful glow.

Far, far above is a stained-glass dome exposing the sky to all within the cathedral. Sunlight fills the cathedral with brilliance, gracing every detail with a nimbus of spectral holy light.The glittering night hangs above, moonlight bathing the cathedral in a soft, soothing peaceful glow.
the floor
Below your feet are white tiles of palest marble, polished to a fine sheen. Looking down you can see your own reflection:
Below your feet are white tiles of palest marble, polished to a fine sheen.
a statue of Saint James, The Great

Depicted in polished marble is a historic statue of a tall, youthful man who stands with a staff grasped in one hand. Long hair drapes over his neck to his shoulders and thin eyebrows detail his face with a thin nose. He dons an ankle-length robe and a pair of slippers, and a capelet is draped over his shoulders to complete his look. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Saint James, The Great-.

Depicted in polished marble is a historic statue of a tall, youthful man who stands with a staff grasped in one hand. Long hair drapes over his neck to his shoulders and thin eyebrows detail his face with a thin nose. He dons an ankle-length robe and a pair of slippers, and a capelet is draped over his shoulders to complete his look. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Saint James, The Great-.
a statue of John, Son of Zebedee

The youngest of all the chosen apostles are depicted within this historic statue crafted of shimmering pure white marble. Resembling his more elderly brother, he has long, flowing locks that brush just against his shoulders. He is draped in a floor-length hooded robe and a small, delicate halo above his head. Slender eyebrows are set above small eyebrows, a medium nose, and thin lips. His hands are clasped together in humble prayer as his gaze looks towards the sky. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -John, Son of Zebedee-.

The youngest of all the chosen apostles are depicted within this historic statue crafted of shimmering pure white marble. Resembling his more elderly brother, he has long, flowing locks that brush just against his shoulders. He is draped in a floor-length hooded robe and a small, delicate halo above his head. Slender eyebrows are set above small eyebrows, a medium nose, and thin lips. His hands are clasped together in humble prayer as his gaze looks towards the sky. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -John, Son of Zebedee-.
the sanctuary lamp

A lit lamp is suspended from the ceiling before the high altar within the sanctuary. The lamp is encased in a gold base and fueled with a sweetly-fragrant oil. Small mirrors around the lamp send forth light in all directions, signifying the presence of God within the sanctuary.
A lit lamp is suspended from the ceiling before the high altar within the sanctuary.
a statue of Honest Nathaniel

A short but sturdy statue crafted of polished marble portrays a youthful man and stands within one of the various pillars. The man has short, curly locks and a matching beard that partially covers his entire chin. Bushy eyebrows sit atop round, sincere eyes while a large nose and thin lips complete his face. He is garbed in a broad swath of fabric that pools to the ground and wraps around his shoulders and body. His face is tilted upward as if he is staring at the sky above with a subtle smile upon his lips. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Honest Nathaniel-.

A short but sturdy statue crafted of polished marble portrays a youthful man and stands within one of the various pillars. The man has short, curly locks and a matching beard that partially covers his entire chin. Bushy eyebrows sit atop round, sincere eyes while a large nose and thin lips complete his face. He is garbed in a broad swath of fabric that pools to the ground and wraps around his shoulders and body. His face is tilted upward as if he is staring at the sky above with a subtle smile upon his lips. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Honest Nathaniel-.
the nave

The nave of the cathedral spans impressively from the narthex to the choir, filled with countless rows of oak pews and flanked on either side by aisles. The pews are of highly polished oak and face the high altar. The aisles are separated from the nave by numerous arches supported by white marble columns.
The nave of the cathedral is the main approach to the high altar from the narthex. It is filled with fixed pews which face to the north and is flanked on either side by a pair of aisles.
a statue of Philip, The Curious

A sturdy, polished statue of a tall, young man who has wavy shoulder-length hair and a bushy beard. He is garbed in a heavy robe that pools at the ground and bears a large cross in his hand. His hands clasp together around the cross in the form of a prayer as his head bowed in reverence. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Philip, The Curious-.

A sturdy, polished statue of a tall, young man who has wavy shoulder-length hair and a bushy beard. He is garbed in a heavy robe that pools at the ground and bears a large cross in his hand. His hands clasp together around the cross in the form of a prayer as his head bowed in reverence. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Philip, The Curious-.
one of the pillars

Lofty, marble pillars adorn the central aisle of the walkway that consists of intricate statues built within depicting important figures of the catholic religion. A small plate is below each statue with a name and information on the depicted person.

Lofty, marble pillars adorn the central aisle of the walkway that consists of intricate statues built within depicting important figures of the catholic religion. A small plate is below each statue with a name and information on the depicted person.
the northern wall's rail
A polished brass rail spans the length of the low granite wall, extending from each wall to either side of the marble arch.
A polished brass rail.
the sanctuary

The sanctuary is an area just to the north of the choir. Two very small sets of stairs, on the east and west, lead from the choir up to the sanctuary, which is raised a couple of feet above the floor of the cathedral. In the center of the sanctuary stands the high altar. Surrounding the sanctuary on all sites is an altar rail made of white marble where worshipers may stand to receive a priest's blessing. The sanctuary itself is the holiest of places within the cathedral, sanctified by God and the power of the high altar.

The sanctuary is an area just to the north of the choir. Two very small sets of stairs, on the east and west, lead from the choir up to the sanctuary, which is raised a couple of feet above the floor of the cathedral. In the center of the sanctuary stands the high altar.
a statue of Simon, Saint Peter

A polished marble statue portrays a tall, elderly man garbed in a floor-length robe. He has short, thin hair and a bushy goatee beard partially obscure his face. His head is bent downward to rest peacefully against his closed palms as he prays. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Simon, Saint Peter-.

A polished marble statue portrays a tall, elderly man garbed in a floor-length robe. He has short, thin hair and a bushy goatee beard partially obscure his face. His head is bent downward to rest peacefully against his closed palms as he prays. A small, golden plate sits below the statue, engraved with the name -Simon, Saint Peter-.
the eastern choir stage

This stage stands on the eastern side of the choir, facing toward the west but angled to the south slightly so that singers can be seen and heard easily by worshipers in the nave. The stage has five levels, arranged in a stair-like fashion, and can hold dozens of singers. This stage is meant for singers who sing in the alto and tenor range.
This stage stands on the eastern side of the choir, facing toward the west but angled to the south slightly so that singers can be seen and heard easily by worshipers in the nave.
the western choir stage

This stage stands on the western side of the choir, facing toward the east but angled to the south slightly so that singers can be seen and heard easily by worshipers in the nave. The stage has five levels, arranged in a stair-like fashion, and can hold dozens of singers. This stage is meant for singers who sing in the bass and soprano range.
This stage stands on the western side of the choir, facing toward the east but angled to the south slightly so that singers can be seen and heard easily by worshipers in the nave.
the eastern transept

The eastern transept is a short hallway leading from the cathedral's crossing to a large set of double doors. The walls of the transept have niches in them holding life-sized statues of women in priestly robes in various poses representing clerical duties.
The eastern transept is a short hallway leading from the cathedral's crossing to a large set of double doors.
the western transept

The western transept is a short hallway leading from the cathedral's crossing to a large set of double doors. The walls of the transept have niches in them holding life-sized statues of men in priestly robes in various poses representing clerical duties.
The western transept is a short hallway leading from the cathedral's crossing to a large set of double doors.
the eastern walls

The eastern walls extend nearly beyond sight to the distant ceiling above. They are made of plaster covered with a brilliant whitewash. Murals cover the walls almost completely in shining tile, showing the revered Don on his deathbed, filled with the holy light of Christ, and dictating his teachings to the apostles.
The eastern walls extend nearly beyond sight to the distant ceiling above. They are made of plaster covered with a brilliant whitewash. Murals cover the walls almost completely in shining tile.
the northern walls

The northern walls extend nearly beyond sight to the distant ceiling above. They are made of plaster covered with a brilliant whitewash. Murals cover the walls almost completely in shining white tile, showing Christ performing various miracles of healing and resurrection.
The northern walls extend nearly beyond sight to the distant ceiling above. They are made of plaster covered with a brilliant whitewash. Murals cover the wall almost completely in shining tile.
the low southern wall

The southern wall is simple in construction. It is roughly waist-high to an average person and any but the smallest child can see over it. It is made of white granite and topped with a polished brass rail. Bisecting the wall is an arch made of white marble.
Over the wall, you see in the narthex:

The southern wall is short and made of smooth white granite. You can easily see over the wall into the rest of the cathedral. Bisecting the wall is an arch made of white marble.
Over the wall, you see in the narthex:
the western walls

The western walls extend nearly beyond sight to the distant ceiling above. They are made of plaster covered with a brilliant whitewash. Murals cover the walls almost completely in shining tile, showing Christ performing the final sacrifice, the giving of his life to save the sinners.
The western walls extend nearly beyond sight to the distant ceiling above. They are made of plaster covered with a brilliant whitewash. Murals cover the walls almost completely in shining tile.
the clerestory windows

The clerestory windows are located high in the walls, displaying holy scenes and symbolism in stained glass. The colors and shapes come alive in the bright sun of the day, glowing with warm ambiance.The windows reflect the ambient candlelight, causing the stained glass to glitter like jewelry.
The clerestory windows are located high in the walls, displaying holy scenes and symbolism in stained glass.
